title: COVID-19: Current State, Vaccines, and Mandates
content: The current state of affairs regarding COVID-19, including the Omicron variant, and a search for the end game. Discussion on the effectiveness of COVID vaccines and the controversy surrounding vaccine mandates. Examination of the role of masks, long COVID, boosters, treatments, and more in the fight against the pandemic.

title: Feedback on Vaccine Mandates
content: Feedback received on the topic of vaccine mandates, with some readers changing their stance after reading the argument presented. Discussion on the scientific evidence surrounding vaccine mandates, rather than the political implications.

title: Impact of Vaccination Decisions
content: Discussion on the broader repercussions of the decision not to vaccinate oneself, including the potential impact on others and the healthcare system. Examination of the risk of hospitalization or death from COVID for unvaccinated individuals, and the potential burden this places on the healthcare system.

title: Arguments Against Vaccine Mandates
content: Argument against vaccine mandates, suggesting that they should be reserved for cases where they significantly impact the outcome. Discussion on the potential for mandates to be unnecessary if a virus was sufficiently deadly and spread easily, as people would likely voluntarily get vaccinated.

title: Omicron Variant and Death Rates
content: Discussion on the Omicron variant of COVID-19, which is more contagious but potentially less virulent than previous variants. Examination of the daily death toll from Omicron, and the potential for some of these deaths to be from other causes in individuals who tested positive for Omicron incidentally.

title: Number Needed to Vaccinate (NNV) for COVID Vaccines
content: Discussion on the calculation of the Number Needed to Vaccinate (NNV) for COVID vaccines, and the potential for this calculation to be misleading. Examination of the Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) and Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) for different age groups, and the potential for the NNV calculation to underestimate the benefit of vaccines in preventing hospitalization and death.

title: Vaccines and COVID-19
content: Vaccines do a great job of protecting the vaccinated. Vaccines do a poor job of preventing transmission. We have very successful treatments–both new drugs and one old drug–to treat COVID. Natural immunity is, at a minimum, as good as vaccine immunity and with each passing day the fraction of people who are not immune, via infection and/or vaccine, is shrinking precipitously. Omicron is less virulent than all variants that preceded it and will eventually infect everyone, with or without a vaccine, thereby providing an excellent booster.

title: U.S. Fatality Statistics
content: Data for annual U.S. fatalities attributable to suicide, homicide, drug overdose, and COVID were sourced from the CDC, while the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) provided data for annual U.S. fatalities from motor vehicle accidents. For suicide, homicide, and drug overdoses, crude death rates were calculated from a 12-month period ending in Q3 of 2020. Motor vehicle-related death rates were calculated from a 12-month period ending in Q4 2019 and COVID-related death rates were calculated from a 12-month period ending in Q1 of 2021. The data for all fatality categories were further stratified by age and reported as rates per 100,000 persons within that age group.

title: Organ Transplant and Vaccination
content: If one argues that not being vaccinated implies poor compliance with subsequent medical care, then yes, this would rightly constitute grounds for deprioritization. If one argues that not being vaccinated increases the risk of organ rejection or subsequent infection that could lead to organ rejection (or death), then yes, this would rightly constitute grounds for deprioritization. The best outcome for a transplant patient–someone who will spend the rest of their life immunocompromised–is likely better if they are vaccinated than if they are not.
